result.execSummary:
The defendant Peter M Hunstiger was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of Child Pornography, a class D felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.12(1m).
  • Possession of Child Pornography, a class D felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.12(1m).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: The Court sentences Mr. Hunstiger   to  6  years Imprisonment on Counts #1 and #2 , with an Initial Term of Confinement in Prison of  3  years, and the maximum time to serve on Extended Supervision of 3  years.  These sentences are to be concurrent to eachother. These sentences are to commence FORTHWITH

superMiscConds.notes:
--to pay costs, fees, assessments and surcharges including the DNA surcharge
--to pay $500 child pornography surcharge (as to Counts #1 and #2 only)

--no unsupervised contact with children under the age of 18, unless approved by DOC

--no possession or use of any cell phone, computer, or electronic device capable of accessing the Internet without DOC approval

--psychosexual evaluation and follow through as recommended by treatment providers and/or DOC

--to undergo assessment, treatment, counseling as required by the Agent

--comply with the Wisconsin Sex Offender Registry

--to comply with DNA sample provision upon demand

Arresting Agency: Wisconsin Department of Justice, Division of Criminal Investigation

If probation, parole or extended supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of the victim(s) and government entities for the balance due.

records.addlTxt:
[MA]Case called at 11:27pm 
Defendant Peter M Hunstiger in court with Attorney Jonathan A. LaVoy.  Monica J. Hall appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
  
Constitutional rights reviewed; maximum penalties recited; pleas of " GUILTY  " entered on Counts #1 and #2; factual basis stipulated; victim rights compliance verified; the Court accepts the plea, finds Mr. Hunstiger   guilty, and orders Judgment of Conviction entered.

On Motion of the State, the Court reads in and dismisses: all remaining counts 

Sentencing arguments given by Counsel

The Court preserves Defense's right to a constitutional challenge

Statement made by Mr. Hunstiger

The Court sentences Mr. Hunstiger   to  6  years Imprisonment on Counts #1 and #2 , with an Initial Term of Confinement in Prison of  3  years, and the maximum time to serve on Extended Supervision of 3  years.  These sentences are to be concurrent to eachother. These sentences are to commence FORTHWITH

The Court finds that the Defendant is NOT eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program "Boot Camp".
The Court finds that the Defendant is eligible for the Substance Abuse Program

The Court gives  2   days credit for time already served.

The Court orders as conditions of Extended Supervision:
--psychosexual evaluation and follow through as recommended by treatment providers and/or DOC
--no unsupervised contact with children under the age of 18, unless approved by DOC
--no possession or use of any cell phone, computer, or electronic device capable of accessing the Internet without DOC approval
--to undergo assessment, treatment, counseling as required by the Agent
--comply with the Wisconsin Sex Offender Registry
--to comply with DNA sample provision upon demand
--to pay costs, fees, assessments and surcharges including the DNA surcharge
--to pay $500 child pornography surcharge (as to Counts #1 and #2 only)

Felony Firearm and Voting-rights prohibitions/warnings given
Explanation of Determinate Sentence form given to the Defendant
recess: 11:50am
submitted by Attorney LaVoy regarding Mr. Hunstiger's treatment

It is Ordered that the Petition for Leave to Appeal is granted. It is further Ordered that the entry of this order has the effect of the filing of a notice of appeal. Pursuant to WIS. STAT. Rule 809.11(2), the clerk of the circuit court or responsible court official shall return the copy of the order granting this petition and the circuit court record of the case maintained pursuant to WIS STAT 59.40 to the clerk of this court within 3 days of receipt of this order. It is further ordered that this appeal is placed on hold pending remittitur or a supreme court decision in State v. Holcomb, Appeal No. 2015AP996-CR.

IT IS HEREBY ORDERED by the COURT that Wis. Stat 939.617 is not ambiguous as to its interpretation. Furthermore it is the ORDER of the COURT that Wis. Stat 939.617(2) does not permit a court to impose a sentence of incarceration that is less than three years in prison unless the Court finds it is in the best interests of the community and the public will not be harmed, and the defendant is not more than 48 months older than the child who engaged in the sexually explicit conduct

Case called at 3:22 pm [Clerk SH]
Defendant Peter M Hunstiger in court with Attorney Jennifer Flynn. ADA Jeffrey Martin Shock appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Atty Flynn reviews ruling made by this Court at last motion, requests the Court review written order, submits to the Court, to be sure it accurately reflects the Court's order and upon a written order being entered that triggers a 14 day time period in which then Mr. Hunstiger could appeal to the Court of Appeals. 
ADA Shock informs the Court that he believes proposed order accurately reflects the Court's rulings
Court informs parties that It will set matter for trial in 2 or 3 months, to allow defense to file appeal and this will allow case to keep moving. 
Court informs Atty Flynn of Court's policy regarding FSSC date being the last date to enter a plea
Court reminds Mr. Hunstiger that his bond/conditions of release remain in effect while case is pending
Recess: 3:31 pm

NEXT: (1) Schedule FSSC 9/27/16 at 1:30 pm - Send notices (2) Schedule JT 10/3-4/16 at 8:30 am - Send notices
Status conference on June 9, 2016 at 03:00 pm.

Case called at 8:37 am [Clerk SH] (On Defendant's Motion to Clarify Minimum Sentence)
Defendant Peter M Hunstiger in court with Attorney Jennifer Flynn. ADA Jeffrey Martin Shock appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Atty Flynn informs the Court that there are still two pending cases at the Court of Appeals regarding the same issues, otherwise will rest on filings
ADA Shock informs the Court that the State has nothing to add in filings
Court/Counsel discuss 939.617(2) and the use of "or" language vs. the use of "and" and age differential

Court concludes that the language in the statute is not ambiguous, and believes that the structure proposed by the State is clearly consistent with that of the statute. Based upon the structure of the statute as argued by the State or in (2) is not disjuntive as argued by the defense. To adopt the defense structure would render (1) superflous because in cases where a person is convicted under 948.12 the Court could deviate and impose a sentence of less than 3 years of confinement if It made findings concerning interest of the public as discussed in (2). Court finds (1) as requiring at least 3 years confinement on any defendant who is convicted for a violation of 948.12 exceptions would only apply when there is a 48 month or less age difference between the defendant and the child. Also adopt the State's reasoning that by placing A and B under 2 specifically the legislature intended both A and B to apply the option to impose a sentence of less than 3 years confinement and the option to impose probation. 
Upon questioning of the Court, Counsel indicate that the do not wish for the Court to engage in an analysis regarding ambiguity.

Court does not require a written order to be filed, but will let the record and minutes stand. If either party wishes to submit an order, they should do so on a 5-day objection as to form
Atty Flynn requests matter be set for additional STC in approximately 3 weeks
ADA Shock presents no objection; Court indicates that It has does not have time in 3 weeks but can push to August or fit in next week
Atty Flynn informs the Court that she would be available next week
Court reminds Mr. Huntsinger that his bond/conditions of release remain in effect while the case is pending
Recess: 9:05 am 

NEXT: (1) Schedule STC 6/9/16 at 3:00 pm - Send notices

Case called at 1:53-pm. [mo]
Defendant Peter M Hunstiger appears via videoconferencing from the Jefferson County Jail, in custody, with Attorney De La Rosa(For Bond Purposes Only).  Public Service Special Prosecutor, Melanie Flint appears for the State of Wisconsin.  

On agreement of counsel, the Court finds that the videoconferencing system is sight and sound sufficient. 

Service of Complaint admitted, reading waived, the charge and maximum penalties are recited. 
The Court finds probable cause to exist in the Criminal Complaint
Preliminary Hearing time limits are waived by both parties.

Bond arguments given by Counsel

The Court requires a $10,000  signature bond, with conditions:
--not to access the Internet by a computer or any other digital device

Atty. De La Rosa indicates that Mr. Hunstinger is not eligible for SPD representation. 
The Court gives Mr. Hunstiger his right to Counsel
recess 2:01  pm.
